review.title: The belief noisy-or model applied to network reliability analysis
review.abstract: One difficulty faced in knowledge engineering for Bayesian Network (BN) is the quan-tification step where the Conditional Probability Tables (CPTs) are determined. The number of parameters included in CPTs increases exponentially with the number of parent variables. The most common solution is the application of the so-called canonical gates. The Noisy-OR (NOR) gate, which takes advantage of the independence of causal interactions, provides a logarithmic reduction of the number of parameters required to specify a CPT. In this paper, an extension of NOR model based on the theory of belief functions, named Belief Noisy-OR (BNOR), is proposed. BNOR is capable of dealing with both aleatory and epistemic uncertainty of the network. Compared with NOR, more rich information which is of great value for making decisions can be got when the available knowledge is uncertain. Specially, when there is no epistemic uncertainty, BNOR degrades into NOR. Additionally, different structures of BNOR are presented in this paper in order to meet various needs of engineers. The application of BNOR model on the reliability evaluation problem of networked systems demonstrates its effectiveness.

sections.heading: 2. Background
sections.text: 2.1. Noisy-OR Modeling The noisy-OR structure was introduced by Pearl 7 to reduce survey efforts in the construction of a Bayesian network. Heckerman and Breese 29 have included the general characteristics of the noisy-OR function and its generalizations in their definition of causal independence. Consider a binary variable Y with n binary parent variables Xi (see Figure 1-a). These variables can be either "True" (T) or "False" (F). Each Xi exerts its influence on a Bayesian network, X must be associated with a probability distribution p (Y).

sections.heading: 3. Belief Noisy-OR model
sections.text: We begin by discussing the uncertainty problem in NOR models. One of the existing approaches to express the uncertainty in NOR is the ImNOR model proposed by Fallet et al. 9. We will analyze the disadvantages of ImNOR and create a new NOR gate with the theory of belief functions.3.1. The uncertainty problem in the NOR structure is classically accepted that observations in the system are partially feasible. For example, it is difficult to determine whether an earthquake has occurred, especially when the size is small and the hypo center is deep. In such a case, there are some uncertainties about the state of the Boolean parent variables and it is intuitive for experts to give the ignorant modality. {T, F} Simon and Weber 26 have investigated a solution based on evidence network and the theory of belief functions to account for the uncertainty in the state of the binary parent variables in AND / OR.

sections.heading: 4. Network reliability analysis
sections.text: In this section, we will discuss the application of BNOR to the problem of network reliability analysis. = > The definition of network reliability and the traditional Bayesian solution are recalled first. (Then, the reliability assessment strategy based on the BNOR model is detailed in detail.4.1. Network reliability and Bayesian network solutions are considered here as two-terminal reliability, defined as the probability that there is an operative path between source node n1 and sink node nN on the network. Nodes are assumed to be operational at any time, and edge failures are assumed to be statistically independent. Let graph G (N, E) represents a network in which N denotes the set of nodes and sink nodes nN. For the network shown in Figure 8-a, N = {n1, n2, n4}, E = {e1, e2, e3, e4}.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, the BNOR model is developed within the framework of belief functions as an extension of the traditional NOR model to express various types of uncertainty in the independent causal interactions. It has been proven that BNOR can be implemented to disseminate unsafe information through the use of Bayesian networking tools. In practice, BNOR is more flexible than existing NOR models because it provides a general Bayesian framework that allows us to adopt the exact inference algorithm in its original form without modification and then adjust necessary parameters to obtain results that meet the specific requirements of engineers. Finally, the application to the reliability problem of networked systems demonstrates the effectiveness of the BNOR model. BNOR is applicable to systems with binary variables. An extension of BNOR that adapts to multi-value variables should be considered a future development. Furthermore, the uncertainty of interlinkages in practice must not be given.
